any_duplicated
text:
Checks for usage of any(duplicated(...)).



any(duplicated(...)) is valid code but requires the evaluation of duplicated() on the entire input first.
There is a more efficient function in base R called anyDuplicated() that is more efficient, both in speed and memory used. anyDuplicated() returns the index of the first duplicated value, or 0 if there is none.
Therefore, we can replace any(duplicated(...)) by anyDuplicated(...) > 0.




x <- c(1:10000, 1, NA)
any(duplicated(x))

[1] TRUE


Use instead:

x <- c(1:10000, 1, NA)
anyDuplicated(x) > 0

[1] TRUE





See ?anyDuplicated

title: lengths
text:
Checks for usage of length() in several functions that apply it to each element of a list, such as lapply(), vapply(), purrr::map(), etc., and replaces it with lengths().



lengths() is faster and more memory-efficient than applying length() on each element of the list.




x <- list(a = 1, b = 2:3, c = 1:10)
sapply(x, length)

 a  b  c 
 1  2 10 


Use instead:

x <- list(a = 1, b = 2:3, c = 1:10)
lengths(x)

 a  b  c 
 1  2 10 





See ?lengths

title: which_grepl
text:
Checks for usage of which(grepl(...)) and replaces it with grep(...).



which(grepl(...)) is harder to read and is less efficient than grep() since it requires two passes on the vector.




x <- c("hello", "there")
which(grepl("hell", x))

[1] 1

which(grepl("foo", x))

integer(0)


Use instead:

x <- c("hello", "there")
grep("hell", x)

[1] 1

grep("foo", x)

integer(0)





See ?grep

title: equals_na
text:
Check for x == NA, x != NA and x %in% NA, and replaces those by is.na() calls.



Comparing a value to NA using == returns NA in many cases:

x <- c(1, 2, 3, NA)
x == NA

[1] NA NA NA NA


which is very likely not the expected output.




x <- c(1, 2, 3, NA)
x == NA

[1] NA NA NA NA


Use instead:

x <- c(1, 2, 3, NA)
is.na(x)

[1] FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE

title: assignment
text:
Checks for usage of = as assignment operator.



This is not “bad” strictly speaking since in most cases using = and <- is equivalent. Some very popular packages use = without problems.
Nonetheless, <- is more popular and this rule may be useful to avoid mixing both operators in a codebase.




x = "a"

Use instead:

x <- "a"




See: * https://style.tidyverse.org/syntax.html#assignment-1 * https://stackoverflow.com/a/1742550

title: duplicated_arguments
text:
Checks for duplicated arguments in function calls.



While some cases of duplicated arguments generate run-time errors (e.g. mean(x = 1:5, x = 2:3)), this is not always the case (e.g. c(a = 1, a = 2)).
This linter is used to discourage explicitly providing duplicate names to objects. Duplicate-named objects are hard to work with programmatically and should typically be avoided.




list(x = 1, x = 2)

$x
[1] 1

$x
[1] 2

title: redundant_equals
redundant_equals
text: Checks for usage of == and != where one of the sides of the operation is TRUE or FALSE.

title: redundant_equals
text: Testing x == TRUE is redundant if x is a logical vector. Wherever this is used to improve readability, the solution should instead be to improve the naming of the object to better indicate that its contents are logical. This can be done using prefixes (is, has, can, etc.). For example, is_child, has_parent_supervision, can_watch_horror_movie clarify their logical nature, while child, parent_supervision, watch_horror_movie don’t.

title: redundant_equals
grepv
text:
Checks for usage of grep(..., value = TRUE) and recommends using grepv() instead (only if the R version used in the project is >= 4.5).



Starting from R 4.5, there is a function grepv() that is identical to grep() except that it uses value = TRUE by default.
Using grepv(...) is therefore more readable than grep(...).




x <- c("hello", "hi", "howdie")
grep("i", x, value = TRUE)

[1] "hi"     "howdie"


Use instead:

x <- c("hello", "hi", "howdie")
grepv("i", x)

[1] "hi"     "howdie"





See ?grepv

title: true_false_symbol
text:
Checks for usage of T and F symbols. If they correspond to the TRUE and FALSE values, then replace them by that. If they correspond to something else, such as an object or a variable name, then no automatic fixes are applied.



T and F are not reserved symbols (like break) and therefore can be used as variable names. Therefore, it is better for readability to replace them by TRUE and FALSE.
It is also recommended to rename objects or parameters named F and T to avoid confusion.




x <- T
y <- F

Use instead:

x <- TRUE
y <- FALSE

title: length_levels
text:
Check for length(levels(...)) and replace it with nlevels(...).



length(levels(...)) is harder to read nlevels(...).
Internally, nlevels() calls length(levels(...)) so there are no performance gains.




x <- factor(1:3)
length(levels(x))

[1] 3


Use instead:

x <- factor(1:3)
nlevels(x)

[1] 3

title: is_numeric
text:
Checks for usage of is.numeric(x) || is.integer(x).



is.numeric(x) returns TRUE when x is double or integer. Therefore, testing is.numeric(x) || is.integer(x) is redundant and can be simplified.




x <- 1:3
is.numeric(x) || is.integer(x)

[1] TRUE


Use instead:

x <- 1:3
is.numeric(x)

[1] TRUE





See ?is.numeric

title: class_equals
text:
Checks for usage of class(...) == "some_class" and class(...) %in% "some_class".



An R object can have several classes. Therefore, class(...) == "some_class" would return a logical vector with as many values as the object has classes, which is rarely desirable.
It is better to use inherits(..., "some_class") instead. inherits() checks whether any of the object’s classes match the desired class.
The same rationale applies to class(...) %in% "some_class".




x <- lm(drat ~ mpg, mtcars)
class(x) <- c("my_class", class(x))

class(x) == "lm"

[1] FALSE  TRUE


Use instead:

x <- lm(drat ~ mpg, mtcars)
class(x) <- c("my_class", class(x))

inherits(x, "lm")

[1] TRUE





See ?inherits

title: sample_int
text:
Checks for usage of sample(1:n, m, ...) and replaces it with sample.int(n, m, ...) for readability.



sample() calls sample.int() internally so they have the same performance, but the latter is more readable.




sample(1:10, 2)

[1] 8 6


Use instead:

sample.int(10, 2)

[1] 7 2





See ?sample

length_test
text:
Checks for usage of length(... == some_val) and replaces it with length(...) == some_val.



This is very likely a mistake since computing the length of the output of == is the same as computing the length of the inputs.




x <- 1:3
length(x == 1)

[1] 3


Use instead:

x <- 1:3
length(x) == 1

[1] FALSE

title: sort
text:
Checks for usage of x[order(x, ...)].



It is better to use sort(x, ...), which is more readable than x[order(x, ...)] and more efficient.




x <- c(3, 2, 5, 1, 5, 6)
x[order(x)]

[1] 1 2 3 5 5 6

x[order(x, na.last = TRUE)]

[1] 1 2 3 5 5 6

x[order(x, decreasing = TRUE)]

[1] 6 5 5 3 2 1


Use instead:

x <- c(3, 2, 5, 1, 5, 6)
sort(x)

[1] 1 2 3 5 5 6

sort(x, na.last = TRUE)

[1] 1 2 3 5 5 6

sort(x, decreasing = TRUE)

[1] 6 5 5 3 2 1





See ?sort
